note.p: William Lewis Sharkey served as Mississippi’s governor in 1865, early in the Reconstruction era.

Born in Sumner County, Tennessee, on July 12, 1798, Sharkey moved with his family to Warren County, Mississippi, in 1804. As an adult, he studied law and began practicing in Natchez, Mississippi, in 1822. Sharkey moved to Vicksburg in 1825 and pursued political office. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served one term from 1828 to 1829.

In 1832, Sharkey married Minerva Cage, a widow with two children. The couple had four children over the next several years. In 1832, Sharkey also became a circuit court judge and was shortly thereafter elected to the High Court of Errors and Appeals, the predecessor to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. He served in that role for 18 years, resigning in 1851. From there, he took a diplomatic appointment for the United States government, serving as U.S. Consul in Havana, Cuba, until 1854. After completing that diplomatic assignment, Sharkey returned to Mississippi and returned to legal and political duties, helping compile the Mississippi Code of 1857.

During the secession crisis in the winter of 1860 and 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election, Sharkey remained a steadfast Unionist. Having been a member of the Whig Party, he retained his opposition to secession and refused to support the Confederacy, even as he remained in Mississippi through the Civil War. Despite his political stance against Mississippi’s secessionist government, Confederate officials left him alone out of respect of his past service to the state as a judge and legal scholar.

After the Confederacy’s defeat, President Andrew Johnson appointed Sharkey provisional governor of Mississippi in June 1865. In that role, he called forth a constitutional convention to meet Johnson’s goal of swiftly restoring former Confederate states to the Union. In October 1865, Benjamin Humphreys won election as Mississippi’s governor. Sharkey did not vacate the office, though, until December 1865, having served less than a year. Although no longer governor, Sharkey was selected by the Mississippi legislature to serve in the U.S. Senate. Federal officials denied him a seat, and the rest of the Mississippi congressional delegation, following the Republican backlash to Mississippi’s Black Codes—a set of racially discriminatory laws passed by the Mississippi legislature in 1865.

Having been denied a U.S. Senate seat, Sharkey returned to practicing law, in Jackson, Mississippi. He died in Washington, D.C., on March 30, 1873, and is buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “William Lewis Sharkey: Twenty-fifth Governor of Mississippi: June to December 1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)

note.p: Bartley Barry Boone was an attorney, Confederate officer, and district judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on April 6, 1831, Boone studied law and became a successful attorney in Mississippi. He entered state politics in the 1850s, serving in the Mississippi House of Representatives and participating in Democratic party conventions as a delegate from Tishomingo in the 1850s. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Boone volunteered for Confederate service. He helped raise a company of volunteers, known as the Tishomingo Riflemen, and was then commissioned as an officer in the Second Mississippi Infantry Regiment.

Boone was the highest Confederate officer captured by Union troops at the First Battle of Bull Run in July 1861. The incident occurred in part due to the irregular uniforms worn by Union and Confederate soldiers during the first major engagement of the Civil War. When soldiers of the First Minnesota Infantry Regiment, wearing red shirts, opened fire on Boone’s Second Mississippi Infantry, he mistook them for the Fourth Alabama Infantry Regiment, which also wore red shirts. Boone rode his horse to the red-shirted infantrymen and ordered them to cease firing on their “friends.” Only when he suddenly found a bayonet at his chest and a demand to surrender did Boone realize his mistake.

Boone survived the Civil War and was again elected to the Mississippi legislature in 1865. In 1866, he was appointed the Ninth Judicial Circuit. Beyond his judicial and legal work, Boone also helped establish the town of Booneville, Mississippi, with land he purchased with G. W. Williams, and W. P. Curlee from members of the Chickasaw Nation. He died in 1905 in that town. Boone was married twice, first to Lou M. Petty, who passed away in 1861. He then married Margaret Petty. He had at least three children who survived to adulthood. Boone is buried in Booneville Cemetery in Booneville, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; “Boone Family,” Tishomingo County Archives & History Museum; Vicksburg Daily Whig, Vicksburg, MS, November 25, 1858; The Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, July 6, 1859; Journal of the House of Representatives, of the State of Mississippi, at a Called Session Thereof, Held in the City of Jackson, July & August 1861, 108; Richard Moe, The Last Full Measure: The Life and Death of the First Minnesota Volunteers, 49)

Robert Andrews Hill was a U.S. District Judge in Oxford, Mississippi from 1866 to 1891.

Born on March 25, 1811 in Iredell County, North Carolina, Hill moved to Iredale County, Tennessee with his family in 1816. In 1844, he became a lawyer, operating in Lewis and Hickman County, Tennessee, but he relocated to Tishomingo, Mississippi in 1855. In 1866, President Andrew Johnson appointed Hill as the United States District Judge operating in Oxford, Mississippi, serving Mississippi and Louisiana. He retained this position until resigning on August 1, 1891, citing his advanced age.

Hill was married to Mary Lucky Gillespie (Andrews) Hill, who preceded him in death in 1898. The pair had one daughter. Hill died on July 2, 1900 in Oxford, Mississippi and was buried in the Oxford Memorial Cemetery.
(Oxford Eagle, March 29, 1894; The Weekly Corinthian, July 4, 1900; FindaGrave)

Currently located in Alcorn County, Jacinto was founded in 1836 in what was then Tishomingo County. It became part of Alcorn County when it was created on April 15, 1870. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)
Located in northeast Mississippi, Tishomingo County was established on February 9, 1836. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia)

Located in Chickasaw County, Okolona was settled in 1845 under the name Rose Hill and was renamed Okolona when it was established in 1859. Okolona serves as county co-seat (with Houston). (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
The Territory of Illinois was established February 3, 1809. Admitted as the 21st state, Illinois achieved statehood on December 3, 1818. (Britannica)

Amnesty takes several forms including: "a decision made by government officials to free a prisoner," "a fixed period of time during which people are not punished for committing a particular crime," or "a decision by a government to forgive people who have committed particular illegal acts or crimes, and not to punish them." (Cambridge Dictionary)

While the U.S. Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. U.S. Congress divides legislators into separate committees who write federal or national legislation, and a vast industry of lobbyists also help members write legislation on behalf of corporate and labor interests. Once written, the proposed legislation is introduced to both houses, and if the bill passes both chambers by a majority vote, it is sent to the U.S. President for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and Congress can overcome the President's veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Legislation. United States. Congress. General Amnesty Act (1865)

gloss.p: The United States Congress General Amnesty Act (1865) was enacted by President Andrew Johnson on May 29, 1865, giving amnesty (or an official pardon) to former Confederates who participated in the Civil War following an oath of allegiance to the United States and the acceptance of the abolition of enslavement. This act excluded high-ranking military leaders and officials, as well as those who committed war crimes. Johnson believed that amnesty was the surest way to rebuild the nation and the General Amnesty Act was one part of his Reconstruction Plan. This act was welcomed by many Northerners who wanted to move on from the Civil War, but was criticized by many radicals who felt the act was too lenient on Confederate actors and wanted those people excluded from society and punished for their actions in the war. (Wikipedia; National Archives)

div.p: The proclamation &c Sent to our County, I learn are at Okalona I however met with the proclamation, in an Ill paper, and immediately proceeded with the organization of the County Officers; So far all have readily complied, will have the business compted in a Short time the copy of the proclamation I have does not mention the Clerk of the Circuit Court, I did not know but it was an oversight in the printer therefore qualified the Acting Clerk R B Boone and requested him to retain the records & c until further orders.
There having been no regulations made for the administration of the Amnesty Oath for our County

County I have instructed the Justice and members of the Board of Police to administer it, The people of Tishomingo are now, as they theretofore were, a Constitution loving, law abiding, conservative people, and should have an opportunity to show their faith by their works.

R A Hill
Judge of Probate

His Excellency Gov Sharkey
Jackson
Miss

R A Hill
Sending oaths of Tishomingo County He has qualified a Circuit Clerk
